results.title: Buffy. Season 3. Part 2. Eps 34-44 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Josh Whedon and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Buffy the vampire slayer”.
Season three of Joss Whedon’s Buffy the vampire slayer saw the show at the height of its fan base and ratings popularity. All over the globe Buffy (Sarah Michelle Gellar) had entered into the consciousness of popular culture. Season two ended with Buffy running away from Sunnydale after having to kill her one true love Angel (David Boreanaz) who had turned into the evil Angelus. Complicating matters further was Buffy’s mother Joyce (Kristine Sutherland) who discovered that her teenage daughter was a vampire slayer. Season three opens on a Sunnydale, minus Buffy which is proving a burden for the rest of the Scooby gang whose vampire skills aren’t on the same level as the slayer (Eps. one, Annie). Buffy eventually returns to Sunnydale to find a new slayer in town, the rough and impulsive Faith (Eps. three, Faith, hope and trick). Each season creator Joss Whedon and his team of writers face the challenge of providing fresh and inventive adversary’s for Buffy and her gang to fight. In season three they rise to the challenge with the introduction of the Mayor (Harry Groener), a villain whose unnerving chirpy demure hilariously clashes with his plans for world domination and the destruction of Sunnydale as we know it. With season three Whedon played up even more the hormonal havoc his teenage leads have to contend with, as Willow (Alyson Hannigan) and Xander (Nicholas Brendon) overstep the line in their friendship and a potential new romance for Buffy is thwarted by the shock return of Angel (Eps. four, Beauty and the beasts). Other highlights include the introduction of Anya (Eps. nine, The wish), a vengeance demon that grants Cordelia’s wish of a Sunnydale without Buffy and the exciting two part finale (Eps. twenty one and twenty two, Graduation day) where the Mayors apocalyptic ‘ascension’ comes to fruition. Cast includes: Seth Green, Charisma Carpenter, Anthony Stuart Head, Eliza Dushku, James Marsters.

results.title: Buffy. Season 2. Part 1. Eps 01-12 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Josh Whedon and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Buffy the vampire slayer”.
Season two of Joss Whedon’s cult series saw the introduction of Vampires Spike (James Marsters) and Drusilla (Juliet Landau) (Ep. 3 School hard), this seasons resident ‘big-bads’. This was the year that “Buffy the Vampire slayer’s” popularity went from small cult following to full blown media event, gaining some of the highest ratings the show has ever had in the US. Season two also saw the introduction of the cool and mysterious Oz (Seth Green), who became a ‘Scooby gang’ regular and a potential love interest for Willow. Unfortunately, like everything else in Sunnydale High, gateway to the hellmouth, Oz has teen issues of the supernatural kind (Ep. 15, Phases). Love is also in the air for Zander (Nicholas Brendan) as he hooks up with the ‘cliquey’ Cordelia (Charisma Carpenter), an unlikely paring which results in much bitchy repartee (Ep. 10, What’s my line, Part two). Aside from a new slayer unexpectedly arriving on the scene (Ep. 9, What’s my line, Part One), season two’s biggest surprise ended up being the transformation of Buffy’s ‘soulful’ vampire boyfriend Angel (David Boreanaz) into the uber evil, Angelus (Ep. 13, Surprise and Ep. 14, Innocence). This causes the love struck Buffy much grief as she has to make some difficult and painful decisions (Ep. 22, Becoming, Part two). Meanwhile, Angelus makes it his personal mission to make the slayer’s life hell (Ep. 17, Passion), while joining forces with Spike and Drusilla as they attempt to awaken a demon that will suck the world into hell (Ep. 21, Becoming, Part one and Eps. 22, Becoming, Part two). Cast includes: Sarah Michele Gellar, Alyson Hannigan, Nicholas Brendan, Anthony Stewart Head.

results.title: With Love to the Person Next to Me
results.creator_credit: Brian McKenzie, John Cruthers and Standard Films
results.brief_description: A comical study in urban alienation and taxi etiquette. Wallace is a taxi driver who lives in a St. Kilda flat with a cast of walking wounded neighbours, all of whom are chronically disconnected like him. He drives the cab at night and spends his days making cider and listening to tapes of the conversations he records secretly in the cab. Those tapes are his only real contact with the world and they allow Wallace to connect with other people’s misery. Cast includes Kim Gyngell, Sally McKenzie, Paul Chubb, Barry Dickens and Daniel Scharf
results.title_for_label: With Love to the Person Next to Me
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian McKenzie, John Cruthers and Standard Films

results.title: Buffy. Season 5. Part 1. Eps 1-11 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Joss Whedon and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Buffy the vampire slayer”.
Buffy season five opens with a deceptively playful episode, (Eps. 79 Buffy Vs. Dracula), where the slayer comes face to face with the celebrated count. Full of the expected smart one-liners and folkloric reinvention, the episode serves to reveal the running thread through this season - what is the full extent and meaning of Buffy’s slayer power? Without a doubt season five is the darkest of the lot but also sees creator Joss Whedon’s writing team at their most ingenious. A case in point, this is the season that Buffy’s little sister Dawn (Michelle Trachtenberg) is revealed (Eps. 79 Buffy Vs. Dracula and Eps. 80 Real me). What role this new addition to the Buffy universe has becomes one of the more inspired inventions that the writers have dreamed up. Also set up in season five is Spike’s unsettling growing attraction to his object of hate, Buffy. (Eps. 82 Out of my mind). This plot strand is a perfect example how ideas are initially set up by Whedon and crew to have long term ramifications for the season and in this case for the entire series. This season’s villain turns out to be the high priestess of insanity, Glory played with exuberant glee by Clare Kramer( Eps. 83 No place like home). What Glory actually is simply goes down as one of the most breathtaking revelations in the series (Eps. 90 Checkpoint). Glory also proves to be quite literally an indestructible foe, lending the season a prevailing sense of fatalism that is ultimately realised in one unforgettable episode, The Body (Eps. 94 The Body). Cast includes: Sarah Michelle Gellar, Nicholas Brendon, Alyson Hannigan, James Marsters, Mark Blucas, Amber Benson, Anthony Stewart Head, Kristine Sutherland, Emma Caulfield.

results.title: With Grandma
results.creator_credit: Francoise Hartmann and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The initial fears of leaving mum and dad behind quickly disappear as dress ups, photographs of grandma as a young girl, games, special food and stories appear that only a grandma can provide as the generation gap between a young girl and an older woman is bridged. A lyrical look, without words, at the shared experiences of a young girl visiting with her grandmother.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Francoise Hartmann and National Film Board of Canada
results.description: The initial fears of leaving mum and dad behind quickly disappear as dress ups, photographs of grandma as a young girl, games, special food and stories appear that only a grandma can provide as the generation gap between a young girl and an older woman is bridged. A lyrical look, without words, at the shared experiences of a young girl visiting with her grandmother.

A lyrical look, without words, at the shared experiences of a young girl visiting with her grandmother.

results.title: Buffy. Season 1. Eps 01-12 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Josh Whedon and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Buffy the vampire slayer”.
Starting life as a moderately successful feature film, “Buffy the vampire slayer” has become a cultural phenomena, spawning thousands of fan sites, a spin-off TV series (Angel), numerous theoretical journals and even it’s own language (Buffy speak). Sixteen year old Buffy Summers (Sarah Michelle Gellar), a typical teenage girl in every respect except one, (she has been destined to slay vampires) moves to Sunnydale, California with her divorced mum. What she is unaware of however is that Sunnydale was built above the ‘hellmouth’, an evil dimension rife with demons and vampires. Buffy reluctantly finds herself burdened with slayer duties again while she struggles to fit into her new high school, date guys and get her homework done. Geller holds her own as the blonde wise cracking, ass-kicking vampire killer but creator Joss Whedon also surrounds her with a strong supporting cast that well and truly hold their own. The ‘Scooby gang’ as they have come to be known consist of computer geek Willow (Alyson Hannigan), the goofy Xander (Nicholas Brendan), the snobby Cordelia (Charisma Carpenter), Buffy’s watcher Gile’s (Anthony Stewart Head) and the brooding vampire with a soul and Buffy love interest, Angel (David Boreanaz). The pleasures in Whedon’s series comes out of the clever play with adolescent angst where every minor humiliation is tantamount to Armageddon and that sometimes it really is. Season one finds Buffy and the Scooby gang battling the Master, an ancient vampire determined to open up the hellmouth and literally create hell on earth. All this and Buffy still has to survive high school.

results.title: Buffy. Season 6. Part 2. Eps 12-22 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Joss Whedon and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Buffy the vampire slayer”.
Season six of Joss Whedon’s cult series is predominately the bleakest one of them all. The ‘Scooby gang’ are all in the throes of relationship hell. Willow (Alyson Hannigan) and Tara’s (Amber Benson) love for each other begins to erode as Willow falls deeper into the black arts (addiction metaphors abound in this season), while Xander (Nicholas Brendon) and Anya (Emma Caulfield) experience pre-wedding jitters with catastrophic consequences (Hell’s bells Eps. 116). Not to mention the fact that Buffy, the vampire slayer, starts this season dead and buried (Bargaining 1&2 Eps. 101 & 102). Considering how downbeat this season is, surprisingly it’s the one with the most light and comical villains, the nerdy three, Jonathan, Andrew and Warren (Flooded Eps. 104) - not to mention that they are mere mortals. It’s also the season that Buffy went musical (Once more with feeling Eps. 107), a Joss Whedon directed episode that proves once and for all how inventive and original this show can be. Buffy’s resurrection (you didn’t think she was going to stay dead did you!) proves to be the season’s overriding story arch as she grapples with being flesh once again and the dire consequences that entails. One of them being a destructive and highly sexual relationship with resident bad boy vampire, Spike (James Marsters).

results.title: Buffy the vampire slayer
results.creator_credit: Gareth Davies and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: For as long as there has been vampires, there’s been the slayer - one girl, hand picked out of the entire world as championing the cause against the creatures of the night. Join Buffy, Giles, Willow, Zander, Cordelia and Angel as they struggle to keep Sunnydale - town at the hellmouth, free from all that is evil, while still mainaining a killer sense of humour and a savvy sense of fashion.

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Buffy the vampire slayer”.
Season six of Joss Whedon’s cult series is predominately the bleakest one of them all. The ‘Scooby gang’ are all in the throes of relationship hell. Willow (Alyson Hannigan) and Tara’s (Amber Benson) love for each other begins to erode as Willow falls deeper into the black arts (addiction metaphors abound in this season), while Xander (Nicholas Brendon) and Anya (Emma Caulfield) experience pre-wedding jitters with catastrophic consequences (Hell’s bells Eps. 116). Not to mention the fact that Buffy, the vampire slayer, starts this season dead and buried (Bargaining 1&2 Eps. 101 & 102). Considering how downbeat this season is, surprisingly it’s the one with the most light and comical villains, the nerdy three, Jonathan, Andrew and Warren (Flooded Eps. 104) - not to mention that they are mere mortals. It’s also the season that Buffy went musical (Once more with feeling Eps. 107), a Joss Whedon directed episode that proves once and for all how inventive and original this show can be. Buffy’s resurrection (you didn’t think she was going to stay dead did you!) proves to be the season’s overriding story arch as she grapples with being flesh once again and the dire consequences that entails. One of them being a destructive and highly sexual relationship with resident bad boy vampire, Spike (James Marsters).
